sn14.28:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, sentient beings join together and converge because of an element:

sn14.28:1.3.eng: those of wrong view with those of wrong view …

sn14.28:2.8.eng: right immersion with those who have right immersion.”

sn14.29:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, sentient beings come together and converge because of an element:

sn14.29:1.3.eng: those of wrong view with those of wrong view …

sn14.29:2.10.eng: right freedom with those who have right freedom.”

sn14.29:2.12.eng: (Tell all in full for the past, future, and present.)

sn14.3:1.2.pli: “Dhātunānattaṃ, bhikkhave, paṭicca uppajjati phassanānattaṃ, no phassanānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhātunānattaṃ.
sn14.3:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, diversity of elements gives rise to diversity of contacts. Diversity of contacts doesn’t give rise to diversity of elements.
sn14.3:1.2.comm: This discourse asserts that, in this case, conditionality is one way. This heads off the assumption that mutual condition applies to all the factors (SN 12.65:2.16).

sn14.3:1.3.eng: And what is the diversity of elements?

sn14.3:1.4.eng: The eye element, ear element, nose element, tongue element, body element, and mind element.

sn14.3:1.6.eng: This is called the diversity of elements.

sn14.3:2.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, dhātunānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati phassanānattaṃ, no phassanānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhātunānattaṃ?
sn14.3:2.1.eng: And how does diversity of elements give rise to diversity of contacts, while diversity of contacts doesn’t give rise to diversity of elements?

sn14.3:2.2.pli: Cakkhudhātuṃ, bhikkhave, paṭicca uppajjati cakkhusamphasso, no cakkhusamphassaṃ paṭicca uppajjati cakkhudhātu …pe…
sn14.3:2.2.eng: The eye element gives rise to eye contact. Eye contact doesn’t give rise to the eye element. …

sn14.3:2.3.pli: manodhātuṃ paṭicca uppajjati manosamphasso, no manosamphassaṃ paṭicca uppajjati manodhātu.
sn14.3:2.3.eng: The mind element gives rise to mind contact. Mind contact doesn’t give rise to the mind element.

sn14.3:2.4.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, dhātunānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati phassanānattaṃ, no phassanānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhātunānattan”ti.
sn14.3:2.4.eng: That’s how diversity of elements gives rise to diversity of contacts, while diversity of contacts doesn’t give rise to diversity of elements.”

sn14.30:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme …
sn14.30:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery. …

sn14.30:1.2.comm: Also called the “principle states” (mahābhūta). Discussed in detail at MN 28:4.1.

sn14.30:1.4.eng: The elements of earth, water, fire, and air.
sn14.30:1.4.comm: The properties of matter that dominate in solids, liquids, plasma, and gases.

sn14.31:1.2.pli: “Pubbeva me, bhikkhave, sambodhā anabhisambuddhassa bodhisattasseva sato etadahosi:
sn14.31:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, before my awakening—when I was still unawakened but intent on awakening—I thought:

sn14.31:1.3.pli: ‘ko nu kho pathavīdhātuyā assādo, ko ādīnavo, kiṃ nissaraṇaṃ;
sn14.31:1.3.eng: ‘What’s the gratification, the drawback, and the escape when it comes to the earth element …

sn14.31:1.4.pli: ko āpodhātuyā assādo, ko ādīnavo, kiṃ nissaraṇaṃ;

sn14.31:1.5.pli: ko tejodhātuyā assādo, ko ādīnavo, kiṃ nissaraṇaṃ;

sn14.31:1.6.pli: ko vāyodhātuyā assādo, ko ādīnavo, kiṃ nissaraṇan’ti?

sn14.31:2.2.pli: ‘yaṃ kho pathavīdhātuṃ paṭicca uppajjati sukhaṃ somanassaṃ, ayaṃ pathavīdhātuyā assādo;
sn14.31:2.2.eng: ‘The pleasure and happiness that arise from the earth element: this is its gratification.

sn14.31:2.3.pli: yaṃ pathavīdhātu aniccā dukkhā vipariṇāmadhammā, ayaṃ pathavīdhātuyā ādīnavo;
sn14.31:2.3.eng: That the earth element is impermanent, suffering, and perishable: this is its drawback.

sn14.31:2.4.pli: yo pathavīdhātuyā chandarāgavinayo chandarāgappahānaṃ, idaṃ pathavīdhātuyā nissaraṇaṃ.
sn14.31:2.4.eng: Removing and giving up desire and greed for the earth element: this is its escape.

sn14.31:2.5.eng: The pleasure and happiness that arise from the water element …

sn14.31:2.6.eng: The pleasure and happiness that arise from the fire element …

sn14.31:2.7.pli: yaṃ vāyodhātuṃ paṭicca uppajjati sukhaṃ somanassaṃ, ayaṃ vāyodhātuyā assādo;
sn14.31:2.7.eng: The pleasure and happiness that arise from the air element: this is its gratification.

sn14.31:2.8.pli: yaṃ vāyodhātu aniccā dukkhā vipariṇāmadhammā, ayaṃ vāyodhātuyā ādīnavo;
sn14.31:2.8.eng: That the air element is impermanent, suffering, and perishable: this is its drawback.

sn14.31:2.9.pli: yo vāyodhātuyā chandarāgavinayo chandarāgappahānaṃ, idaṃ vāyodhātuyā nissaraṇaṃ’.
sn14.31:2.9.eng: Removing and giving up desire and greed for the air element: this is its escape.’

sn14.31:3.1.pli: Yāvakīvañcāhaṃ, bhikkhave, imāsaṃ catunnaṃ dhātūnaṃ evaṃ assādañca assādato ādīnavañca ādīnavato nissaraṇañca nissaraṇato yathābhūtaṃ na abbhaññāsiṃ, neva tāvāhaṃ, bhikkhave, sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambuddhoti paccaññāsiṃ.
sn14.31:3.1.eng: As long as I didn’t truly understand these four elements’ gratification, drawback, and escape in this way for what they are, I didn’t announce my supreme perfect awakening in this world with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans.
sn14.31:3.1.comm: The four noble truths were similarly extolled in the first discourse (SN 56.11), and this was subsequently said of several major teaching frameworks. Seeing one part of the Dhamma implies seeing them all.

sn14.31:4.1.pli: Yato ca khvāhaṃ, bhikkhave, imāsaṃ catunnaṃ dhātūnaṃ evaṃ assādañca assādato ādīnavañca ādīnavato nissaraṇañca nissaraṇato yathābhūtaṃ abbhaññāsiṃ, athāhaṃ, bhikkhave, sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambuddhoti paccaññāsiṃ.
sn14.31:4.1.eng: But when I did truly understand these four elements’ gratification, drawback, and escape in this way for what they are, I announced my supreme perfect awakening in this world with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans.

sn14.31:4.2.eng: Knowledge and vision arose in me:

sn14.31:4.3.pli: ‘akuppā me vimutti, ayamantimā jāti, natthi dāni punabbhavo’”ti.
sn14.31:4.3.eng: ‘My freedom is unshakable; this is my last rebirth; now there’ll be no more future lives.’”

sn14.32:1.2.pli: “Pathavīdhātuyāhaṃ, bhikkhave, assādapariyesanaṃ acariṃ, yo pathavīdhātuyā assādo tadajjhagamaṃ, yāvatā pathavīdhātuyā assādo paññāya me so sudiṭṭho.
sn14.32:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, I went in search of the earth element’s gratification, and I found it. I’ve seen clearly with wisdom the full extent of gratification in the earth element.
sn14.32:1.2.comm: Said also of the world (AN 3.104), the aggregates (SN 22.27), and the senses (SN 35.15, 16).

sn14.32:1.3.pli: Pathavīdhātuyāhaṃ, bhikkhave, ādīnavapariyesanaṃ acariṃ, yo pathavīdhātuyā ādīnavo tadajjhagamaṃ, yāvatā pathavīdhātuyā ādīnavo paññāya me so sudiṭṭho.
sn14.32:1.3.eng: I went in search of the earth element’s drawback, and I found it. I’ve seen clearly with wisdom the full extent of the drawback in the earth element.

sn14.32:1.4.pli: Pathavīdhātuyāhaṃ, bhikkhave, nissaraṇapariyesanaṃ acariṃ, yaṃ pathavīdhātuyā nissaraṇaṃ tadajjhagamaṃ, yāvatā pathavīdhātuyā nissaraṇaṃ paññāya me taṃ sudiṭṭhaṃ.
sn14.32:1.4.eng: I went in search of escape from the earth element, and I found it. I’ve seen clearly with wisdom the full extent of escape from the earth element.

sn14.32:2.1.eng: I went in search of the water element’s gratification …

sn14.32:2.2.eng: I went in search of the fire element’s gratification …

sn14.32:2.3.pli: vāyodhātuyāhaṃ, bhikkhave, assādapariyesanaṃ acariṃ, yo vāyodhātuyā assādo tadajjhagamaṃ, yāvatā vāyodhātuyā assādo paññāya me so sudiṭṭho.
sn14.32:2.3.eng: I went in search of the air element’s gratification …

sn14.32:2.4.pli: Vāyodhātuyāhaṃ, bhikkhave, ādīnavapariyesanaṃ acariṃ, yo vāyodhātuyā ādīnavo tadajjhagamaṃ, yāvatā vāyodhātuyā ādīnavo paññāya me so sudiṭṭho.

sn14.32:2.5.pli: Vāyodhātuyāhaṃ, bhikkhave, nissaraṇapariyesanaṃ acariṃ, yaṃ vāyodhātuyā nissaraṇaṃ tadajjhagamaṃ, yāvatā vāyodhātuyā nissaraṇaṃ paññāya me taṃ sudiṭṭhaṃ.

sn14.32:3.1.pli: Yāvakīvañcāhaṃ, bhikkhave, imāsaṃ catunnaṃ dhātūnaṃ assādañca assādato ādīnavañca ādīnavato nissaraṇañca nissaraṇato yathābhūtaṃ na abbhaññāsiṃ, neva tāvāhaṃ, bhikkhave, sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambuddhoti paccaññāsiṃ.
sn14.32:3.1.eng: As long as I didn’t truly understand these four elements’ gratification, drawback, and escape for what they are, I didn’t announce my supreme perfect awakening in this world with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans.

sn14.32:4.1.pli: Yato ca khvāhaṃ, bhikkhave, imāsaṃ catunnaṃ dhātūnaṃ assādañca assādato ādīnavañca ādīnavato nissaraṇañca nissaraṇato yathābhūtaṃ abbhaññāsiṃ, athāhaṃ, bhikkhave, sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambuddhoti paccaññāsiṃ.
sn14.32:4.1.eng: But when I did truly understand the four elements’ gratification, drawback, and escape for what they are, I announced my supreme perfect awakening in this world with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans.

sn14.32:4.2.eng: Knowledge and vision arose in me:

sn14.32:4.3.pli: ‘akuppā me vimutti, ayamantimā jāti, natthi dāni punabbhavo’”ti.
sn14.32:4.3.eng: ‘My freedom is unshakable; this is my last rebirth; now there’ll be no more future lives.’”

sn14.33:1.2.pli: “No cedaṃ, bhikkhave, pathavīdhātuyā assādo abhavissa, nayidaṃ sattā pathavīdhātuyā sārajjeyyuṃ.
sn14.33:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, if there were no gratification in the earth element, sentient beings wouldn’t be aroused by it.
sn14.33:1.2.comm: Said also of the world (AN 3.105), the aggregates (SN 22.28), and the senses (SN 35.17, 18).

sn14.33:1.3.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, atthi pathavīdhātuyā assādo, tasmā sattā pathavīdhātuyā sārajjanti.
sn14.33:1.3.eng: But since there is gratification in the earth element, sentient beings are aroused by it.

sn14.33:1.4.pli: No cedaṃ, bhikkhave, pathavīdhātuyā ādīnavo abhavissa, nayidaṃ sattā pathavīdhātuyā nibbindeyyuṃ.
sn14.33:1.4.eng: If the earth element had no drawback, sentient beings wouldn’t grow disillusioned with it.

sn14.33:1.5.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, atthi pathavīdhātuyā ādīnavo, tasmā sattā pathavīdhātuyā nibbindanti.
sn14.33:1.5.eng: But since the earth element has a drawback, sentient beings do grow disillusioned with it.

sn14.33:1.6.pli: No cedaṃ, bhikkhave, pathavīdhātuyā nissaraṇaṃ abhavissa, nayidaṃ sattā pathavīdhātuyā nissareyyuṃ.
sn14.33:1.6.eng: If there were no escape from the earth element, sentient beings wouldn’t escape from it.

sn14.33:1.7.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, atthi pathavīdhātuyā nissaraṇaṃ, tasmā sattā pathavīdhātuyā nissaranti.
sn14.33:1.7.eng: But since there is an escape from the earth element, sentient beings do escape from it.

sn14.33:2.1.pli: No cedaṃ, bhikkhave, āpodhātuyā assādo abhavissa …pe…
sn14.33:2.1.eng: If there were no gratification in the water element …

sn14.33:2.2.eng: If there were no gratification in the fire element …

sn14.33:2.3.pli: no cedaṃ, bhikkhave, vāyodhātuyā assādo abhavissa, nayidaṃ sattā vāyodhātuyā sārajjeyyuṃ.
sn14.33:2.3.eng: If there were no gratification in the air element …

sn14.33:2.4.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, atthi vāyodhātuyā assādo, tasmā sattā vāyodhātuyā sārajjanti.

sn14.33:2.5.pli: No cedaṃ, bhikkhave, vāyodhātuyā ādīnavo abhavissa, nayidaṃ sattā vāyodhātuyā nibbindeyyuṃ.

sn14.33:2.6.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, atthi vāyodhātuyā ādīnavo, tasmā sattā vāyodhātuyā nibbindanti.

sn14.33:2.7.pli: No cedaṃ, bhikkhave, vāyodhātuyā nissaraṇaṃ abhavissa, nayidaṃ sattā vāyodhātuyā nissareyyuṃ.

sn14.33:2.8.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, atthi vāyodhātuyā nissaraṇaṃ, tasmā sattā vāyodhātuyā nissaranti.

sn14.33:3.1.pli: Yāvakīvañcime, bhikkhave, sattā imāsaṃ catunnaṃ dhātūnaṃ assādañca assādato ādīnavañca ādīnavato nissaraṇañca nissaraṇato yathābhūtaṃ na abbhaññaṃsu, neva tāvime, bhikkhave, sattā sadevakā lokā samārakā sabrahmakā sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya nissaṭā visaṃyuttā vippamuttā vimariyādikatena cetasā vihariṃsu.
sn14.33:3.1.eng: As long as sentient beings don’t truly understand these four elements’ gratification, drawback, and escape for what they are, they haven’t escaped from this world—with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans—and they don’t live detached, liberated, with mind free of boundaries.

sn14.33:4.1.pli: Yato ca kho, bhikkhave, sattā imāsaṃ catunnaṃ dhātūnaṃ assādañca assādato ādīnavañca ādīnavato nissaraṇañca nissaraṇato yathābhūtaṃ abbhaññaṃsu, atha, bhikkhave, sattā sadevakā lokā samārakā sabrahmakā sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya nissaṭā visaṃyuttā vippamuttā vimariyādikatena cetasā viharantī”ti.
sn14.33:4.1.eng: But when sentient beings truly understand these four elements’ gratification, drawback, and escape for what they are, they’ve escaped from this world—with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans—and they live detached, liberated, with mind free of boundaries.”
sn14.33:4.1.comm: For “boundary” (mariyādā) see Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 1.4.1.17, where a river forms the “boundary” between Kosala and Videha.

sn14.34:1.2.pli: “Pathavīdhātu ce hidaṃ, bhikkhave, ekantadukkhā abhavissa dukkhānupatitā dukkhāvakkantā anavakkantā sukhena, nayidaṃ sattā pathavīdhātuyā sārajjeyyuṃ.
sn14.34:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, if the earth element were exclusively painful—soaked and steeped in pain and not steeped in pleasure—sentient beings wouldn’t be aroused by it.
sn14.34:1.2.comm: Said also of the aggregates (SN 22.60).

sn14.34:1.3.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, pathavīdhātu sukhā sukhānupatitā sukhāvakkantā anavakkantā dukkhena, tasmā sattā pathavīdhātuyā sārajjanti.
sn14.34:1.3.eng: But because the earth element is pleasurable—soaked and steeped in pleasure and not steeped in pain—sentient beings are aroused by it.

sn14.34:2.3.pli: vāyodhātu ce hidaṃ, bhikkhave, ekantadukkhā abhavissa dukkhānupatitā dukkhāvakkantā anavakkantā sukhena, nayidaṃ sattā vāyodhātuyā sārajjeyyuṃ.

sn14.34:2.4.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, vāyodhātu sukhā sukhānupatitā sukhāvakkantā anavakkantā dukkhena, tasmā sattā vāyodhātuyā sārajjanti.

sn14.34:3.1.pli: Pathavīdhātu ce hidaṃ, bhikkhave, ekantasukhā abhavissa sukhānupatitā sukhāvakkantā anavakkantā dukkhena, nayidaṃ sattā pathavīdhātuyā nibbindeyyuṃ.
sn14.34:3.1.eng: If the earth element was perfectly pleasurable—soaked and steeped in pleasure and not steeped in pain—sentient beings wouldn’t grow disillusioned with it.

sn14.34:3.2.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, pathavīdhātu dukkhā dukkhānupatitā dukkhāvakkantā anavakkantā sukhena, tasmā sattā pathavīdhātuyā nibbindanti.
sn14.34:3.2.eng: But because the earth element is painful—soaked and steeped in pain and not steeped in pleasure—sentient beings do grow disillusioned with it.

sn14.34:4.3.pli: vāyodhātu ce hidaṃ, bhikkhave, ekantasukhā abhavissa sukhānupatitā sukhāvakkantā anavakkantā dukkhena, nayidaṃ sattā vāyodhātuyā nibbindeyyuṃ.
sn14.34:4.3.eng: If the air element was perfectly pleasurable—soaked and steeped in pleasure and not steeped in pain—sentient beings wouldn’t grow disillusioned with it.

sn14.34:4.4.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, vāyodhātu dukkhā dukkhānupatitā dukkhāvakkantā anavakkantā sukhena, tasmā sattā vāyodhātuyā nibbindantī”ti.
sn14.34:4.4.eng: But because the air element is painful—soaked and steeped in pain and not steeped in pleasure—sentient beings do grow disillusioned with it.”

sn14.35:1.2.pli: “Yo, bhikkhave, pathavīdhātuṃ abhinandati, dukkhaṃ so abhinandati.
sn14.35:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, if you take pleasure in the earth element, you take pleasure in suffering.
sn14.35:1.2.comm: Said also of the aggregates (SN 22.29) and the senses (SN 35.19, 20).

sn14.35:1.3.pli: Yo dukkhaṃ abhinandati, ‘aparimutto so dukkhasmā’ti vadāmi.
sn14.35:1.3.eng: If you take pleasure in suffering, you’re not free from suffering, I say.

sn14.35:1.4.eng: If you take pleasure in the water element …

sn14.35:1.5.eng: If you take pleasure in the fire element …

sn14.35:1.6.pli: yo vāyodhātuṃ abhinandati, dukkhaṃ so abhinandati.
sn14.35:1.6.eng: If you take pleasure in the air element, you take pleasure in suffering.

sn14.35:1.7.pli: Yo dukkhaṃ abhinandati, ‘aparimutto so dukkhasmā’ti vadāmi.
sn14.35:1.7.eng: If you take pleasure in suffering, you’re not free from suffering, I say.

sn14.35:2.1.pli: Yo ca kho, bhikkhave, pathavīdhātuṃ nābhinandati, dukkhaṃ so nābhinandati.
sn14.35:2.1.eng: If you don’t take pleasure in the earth element, you don’t take pleasure in suffering.

sn14.35:2.2.pli: Yo dukkhaṃ nābhinandati, ‘parimutto so dukkhasmā’ti vadāmi.
sn14.35:2.2.eng: If you don’t take pleasure in suffering, you’re free from suffering, I say.

sn14.35:2.3.eng: If you don’t take pleasure in the water element …

sn14.35:2.4.eng: If you don’t take pleasure in the fire element …

sn14.35:2.5.pli: yo vāyodhātuṃ nābhinandati, dukkhaṃ so nābhinandati.
sn14.35:2.5.eng: If you don’t take pleasure in the air element, you don’t take pleasure in suffering.

sn14.35:2.6.pli: Yo dukkhaṃ nābhinandati, ‘parimutto so dukkhasmā’ti vadāmī”ti.
sn14.35:2.6.eng: If you don’t take pleasure in suffering, you’re free from suffering, I say.”

sn14.36:1.2.pli: “Yo, bhikkhave, pathavīdhātuyā uppādo ṭhiti abhinibbatti pātubhāvo, dukkhasseso uppādo rogānaṃ ṭhiti jarāmaraṇassa pātubhāvo.
sn14.36:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, the arising, continuation, and manifestation and regeneration of the earth element is the arising of suffering, the continuation of diseases, and the manifestation of old age and death.
sn14.36:1.2.comm: Said also of the aggregates (SN 22.30), and the senses (SN 35.21, 22), this template gets its own Saṁyutta (SN 26). | The first phrase in this template consistently has four terms, the final two of which (abhinibbatti and pātubhāva) are synonyms appearing together in the stock definition of “rebirth” (SN 12.2:4.2). The following phrase, however, only has three: arising (uppāda), continuing (ṭhiti), and manifestation (pātubhāva). I take abhinibbatti and pātubhāva as reinforcing synonyms, the purpose of which is to clarify that the phrase does, in fact, mean a new rebirth. The three phases then correspond to the rebirth, continuation of life, and passing away to be reborn anew, “the manifestation of regeneration”.

sn14.36:1.3.eng: The arising, continuation, and manifestation and regeneration of the water element …

sn14.36:1.4.eng: The arising, continuation, and manifestation and regeneration of the fire element …

sn14.36:1.5.pli: yo vāyodhātuyā uppādo ṭhiti abhinibbatti pātubhāvo, dukkhasseso uppādo rogānaṃ ṭhiti jarāmaraṇassa pātubhāvo.
sn14.36:1.5.eng: The arising, continuation, and manifestation and regeneration of the air element is the arising of suffering, the continuation of diseases, and the manifestation of old age and death.

sn14.36:2.1.pli: Yo ca kho, bhikkhave, pathavīdhātuyā nirodho vūpasamo atthaṅgamo, dukkhasseso nirodho rogānaṃ vūpasamo jarāmaraṇassa atthaṅgamo.
sn14.36:2.1.eng: The cessation, settling, and disappearance of the earth element is the cessation of suffering, the settling of diseases, and the disappearance of old age and death.

sn14.36:2.2.eng: The cessation, settling, and ending of the water element …

sn14.36:2.3.eng: The cessation, settling, and ending of the fire element …

sn14.36:2.4.pli: yo vāyodhātuyā nirodho vūpasamo atthaṅgamo, dukkhasseso nirodho rogānaṃ vūpasamo jarāmaraṇassa atthaṅgamo”ti.
sn14.36:2.4.eng: The cessation, settling, and disappearance of the air element is the cessation of suffering, the settling of diseases, and the disappearance of old age and death.”

sn14.37:1.4.eng: The elements of earth, water, fire, and air.

sn14.37:1.5.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā imāsaṃ catunnaṃ dhātūnaṃ assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti,
sn14.37:1.5.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly understand these four elements’ gratification, drawback, and escape.

sn14.37:1.6.pli: na me te, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā samaṇesu vā samaṇasammatā brāhmaṇesu vā brāhmaṇasammatā; na ca pana te āyasmanto sāmaññatthaṃ vā brahmaññatthaṃ vā diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharanti.
sn14.37:1.6.eng: I don’t deem them as true ascetics and brahmins. Those venerables don’t realize the goal of life as an ascetic or brahmin, and don’t live having realized it with their own insight.

sn14.37:2.1.pli: Ye ca kho keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā imāsaṃ catunnaṃ dhātūnaṃ assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ pajānanti,
sn14.37:2.1.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins who do truly understand these four elements’ gratification, drawback, and escape.

sn14.37:2.2.pli: te ca kho me, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā samaṇesu ceva samaṇasammatā brāhmaṇesu ca brāhmaṇasammatā; te ca panāyasmanto sāmaññatthañca brahmaññatthañca diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharantī”ti.
sn14.37:2.2.eng: I deem them as true ascetics and brahmins. Those venerables realize the goal of life as an ascetic or brahmin, and live having realized it with their own insight.”

sn14.38:1.4.eng: The elements of earth, water, fire, and air.

sn14.38:1.5.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā imāsaṃ catunnaṃ dhātūnaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti …pe…
sn14.38:1.5.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly understand these four elements’ origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape …

sn14.38:1.7.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins who do truly understand these four elements’ origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape …”

sn14.39:1.2.pli: “Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā pathavīdhātuṃ nappajānanti, pathavīdhātusamudayaṃ nappajānanti, pathavīdhātunirodhaṃ nappajānanti, pathavīdhātunirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ nappajānanti …pe…
sn14.39:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, there are ascetics and brahmins who don’t understand the earth element, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation.

sn14.39:1.3.eng: They don’t understand the water element …

sn14.39:1.5.pli: vāyodhātuṃ nappajānanti, vāyodhātusamudayaṃ nappajānanti, vāyodhātunirodhaṃ nappajānanti, vāyodhātunirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ nappajānanti, na me te, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā samaṇesu vā samaṇasammatā brāhmaṇesu vā brāhmaṇasammatā;

sn14.39:1.6.pli: na ca pana te āyasmanto sāmaññatthaṃ vā brahmaññatthaṃ vā diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharanti.
sn14.39:1.6.eng: Those venerables don’t realize the goal of life as an ascetic or brahmin, and don’t live having realized it with their own insight.

sn14.39:2.1.pli: Ye ca kho keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā pathavīdhātuṃ pajānanti, pathavīdhātusamudayaṃ pajānanti, pathavīdhātunirodhaṃ pajānanti, pathavīdhātunirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ pajānanti …
sn14.39:2.1.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins who do understand the earth element, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation.

sn14.39:2.2.pli: ye ca kho keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā …pe… āpodhātuṃ pajānanti …
sn14.39:2.2.eng: They do understand the water element …

sn14.39:2.4.pli: vāyodhātuṃ pajānanti, vāyodhātusamudayaṃ pajānanti, vāyodhātunirodhaṃ pajānanti, vāyodhātunirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ pajānanti, te ca kho me, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā samaṇesu ceva samaṇasammatā brāhmaṇesu ca brāhmaṇasammatā;

sn14.39:2.5.pli: te ca panāyasmanto sāmaññatthañca brahmaññatthañca diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharantī”ti.
sn14.39:2.5.eng: Those venerables realize the goal of life as an ascetic or brahmin, and live having realized it with their own insight.”

sn14.39:3.5.eng: The Linked Discourses on the elements are complete.

sn14.4:1.2.pli: “Dhātunānattaṃ, bhikkhave, paṭicca uppajjati phassanānattaṃ, phassanānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati vedanānānattaṃ.
sn14.4:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, diversity of elements gives rise to diversity of contacts, and diversity of contacts gives rise to diversity of feelings.

sn14.4:1.3.eng: And what is the diversity of elements?

sn14.4:1.4.eng: The eye element, ear element, nose element, tongue element, body element, and mind element.

sn14.4:1.5.eng: This is called the diversity of elements.

sn14.4:2.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, dhātunānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati phassanānattaṃ, phassanānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati vedanānānattaṃ?
sn14.4:2.1.eng: And how does diversity of elements give rise to diversity of contacts, and diversity of contacts gives rise to diversity of feelings?

sn14.4:2.2.pli: Cakkhudhātuṃ, bhikkhave, paṭicca uppajjati cakkhusamphasso, cakkhusamphassaṃ paṭicca uppajjati cakkhusamphassajā vedanā …pe…
sn14.4:2.2.eng: The eye element gives rise to eye contact. Eye contact gives rise to the feeling born of eye contact. …

sn14.4:2.3.pli: manodhātuṃ paṭicca uppajjati manosamphasso, manosamphassaṃ paṭicca uppajjati manosamphassajā vedanā.
sn14.4:2.3.eng: The mind element gives rise to mind contact. Mind contact gives rise to the feeling born of mind contact.

sn14.4:2.4.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, dhātunānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati phassanānattaṃ, phassanānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati vedanānānattan”ti.
sn14.4:2.4.eng: That’s how diversity of elements gives rise to diversity of contacts, and diversity of contacts gives rise to diversity of feelings.”
